definitions: having died out completely and no longer existing as a species or entity
no longer burning, active, or erupting, especially of volcanoes
examples: The dodo became extinct over three centuries ago
Scientists worry these animals might become extinct soon
The extinct volcano poses no threat to nearby villages
They explored the extinct volcanic crater last summer

definitions: having been put out or quenched, especially of fire or light
having been destroyed or suppressed, especially of emotions or hopes
examples: The extinguished campfire still smelled of smoke
All extinguished candles were removed from the altar
Her extinguished hopes left her feeling empty inside
His extinguished passion for music never returned

definitions: more than is usual, expected, or necessary; additional or supplementary
of superior quality or exceptional standard beyond the ordinary
examples: She ordered extra cheese on her pizza tonight
The teacher gave them extra homework this weekend
They paid for extra special treatment at the resort
This fabric has extra fine quality and texture

definitions: falling outside the regular academic curriculum or program of study
examples: Students participate in many extracurricular activities after school
Her extracurricular achievements impressed the college admissions committee

definitions: occurring or done outside the authority of the judicial system or court proceedings
examples: The committee condemned extrajudicial killings by security forces
Extrajudicial settlements often save time and legal costs

definitions: occurring outside marriage, especially referring to sexual relationships with someone other than one's spouse
examples: His extramarital affair destroyed their twenty-year marriage
The survey examined attitudes toward extramarital relationships

definitions: irrelevant or unrelated to the subject being dealt with or considered
coming from outside; of external origin rather than being an essential part
examples: Please remove all extraneous details from your report
The essay contained too many extraneous arguments
Extraneous noise from the street disrupted the recording
They eliminated extraneous variables from the experiment

definitions: very unusual, remarkable, or surprising; going beyond what is ordinary or usual
outside the normal course of regular procedure or authority
examples: She showed extraordinary courage during the crisis
The artist has extraordinary talent for capturing emotion
The board called an extraordinary meeting this afternoon
Parliament convened in extraordinary session last night

definitions: of or from outside the earth or its atmosphere; relating to life from other planets
examples: Scientists search for extraterrestrial life in distant galaxies
The movie featured an extraterrestrial invasion of Earth

definitions: lacking restraint in spending money or using resources; exceeding reasonable bounds
going beyond what is reasonable, moderate, or appropriate; excessive in degree
examples: Their extravagant lifestyle led to serious debt problems
She wore an extravagant gown to the charity gala
He made extravagant claims about his business success
Her extravagant praise made everyone feel uncomfortable

definitions: reaching a high or the highest degree; situated at the furthest point
very severe, serious, or intense in nature or degree
far from moderate, especially politically; holding radical or unconventional views
examples: They live in the extreme north of Scotland
She stood at the extreme edge of the cliff
The region experiences extreme weather conditions every winter
He was in extreme pain after the accident
His extreme political views alienated many supporters
She takes an extreme position on environmental issues

definitions: holding extreme political or religious views, especially ones supporting illegal or violent action
examples: Extremist groups threatened violence against the government
The extremist ideology attracted disaffected young people

definitions: not part of the essential nature of something; coming or operating from outside
examples: Extrinsic motivation comes from external rewards and punishments
The artwork's extrinsic value exceeded its artistic merit

definitions: having a personality that is energized by being around other people; socially confident and outgoing
examples: Her extroverted nature made her perfect for sales
Extroverted students often dominate classroom discussions

definitions: filled with or characterized by lively energy, excitement, and cheerfulness
growing luxuriantly or profusely; characterized by lavish abundance
examples: The children's exuberant laughter filled the playground
She gave an exuberant performance on opening night
The garden displayed exuberant growth after the rain
Exuberant tropical vegetation covered the ancient ruins

definitions: having eyes of a specified kind or number, usually used in combination
examples: The blue-eyed baby smiled at her mother
A one-eyed pirate appeared in his nightmare

definitions: fabulous; wonderful or marvelous, used as informal enthusiastic approval
examples: She looked absolutely fab in her new dress
They had a fab time at the concert

definitions: famous, especially through being described in stories over many years
existing only in fables, myths, or legends; not real but imaginary
examples: They finally reached the fabled city of gold
The fabled hospitality of the region impressed visitors
Dragons and other fabled creatures populated medieval tales
The fabled fountain of youth never actually existed

definitions: made or constructed, especially in a factory or workshop; manufactured
invented in order to deceive; made up or falsely created
examples: The fabricated steel beams arrived at the construction site
They used fabricated components to speed up assembly
The witness gave completely fabricated testimony in court
His fabricated excuse didn't fool anyone

definitions: extraordinary, especially extraordinarily large or good; wonderful or marvelous
barely credible; belonging to fables or myths rather than reality
examples: The hotel offered fabulous views of the ocean
She wore a fabulous diamond necklace to the gala
Tales of fabulous beasts entertained medieval audiences
The explorer searched for fabulous lost treasures

definitions: having a face or surface of a specified type, often used in combinations
confronted with or positioned toward something, especially a difficulty
examples: The stone-faced detective revealed nothing during questioning
A fresh-faced recruit joined the team yesterday
They were faced with an impossible decision
The committee is faced with budget constraints

definitions: lacking a face or having a face that cannot be seen clearly
lacking identity or individuality; impersonal and anonymous in character
examples: A faceless figure appeared in her nightmares
The faceless mannequin stood in the window
Faceless bureaucrats made decisions affecting millions
The faceless corporation ignored customer complaints

definitions: having many flat surfaces, especially cut into a gemstone or crystal
examples: The faceted crystal caught the light beautifully
She wore earrings with faceted blue gems

definitions: of, relating to, or affecting the face or its appearance
examples: She developed a new facial recognition software system
His facial expression revealed his true feelings

definitions: produced without effort or careful thought; superficial or oversimplified
achieved easily or without proper consideration of difficulties; glib
examples: His facile explanation ignored the real complexity
The report offered only facile solutions to deep problems
She dismissed his facile victory over weak opponents
Their facile optimism annoyed the realistic planners

definitions: concerned with or based on facts rather than interpretations or opinions
examples: The report contained several factual errors about dates
She gave a factual account of the incident

definitions: having lost brightness, color, or strength through age or exposure
having diminished in vigor, freshness, or importance over time
examples: She wore faded jeans and an old t-shirt
The faded photograph showed her grandparents' wedding
His faded glory as a champion seemed distant now
The faded beauty of the old mansion remained evident

definitions: relating to or consisting of feces or bodily waste matter
examples: The doctor ordered a faecal test for parasites
Faecal contamination posed serious health risks

definitions: becoming weaker or less effective; declining in health or strength
not achieving success or the desired results; unsuccessful
examples: His failing health worried his family greatly
The failing light made reading difficult
The failing business needed immediate financial help
Her failing grades required extra tutoring sessions

definitions: barely perceptible; lacking clarity, brightness, or volume
lacking conviction, force, or enthusiasm; weak or slight
feeling weak and dizzy; close to losing consciousness
examples: A faint smell of roses filled the room
They heard faint music from the neighbors
She made a faint attempt to smile
He had only faint hope of success
She felt faint after standing in the heat
The faint patient needed immediate medical attention

definitions: treating people equally without favoritism or discrimination; just and reasonable
having light or pale coloring, especially of hair or skin
considerable though not outstanding in size, amount, or quality
of weather that is fine and dry; free from storms
pleasing to look at; beautiful or attractive in an old-fashioned way
examples: The judge made a fair decision in the case
Everyone deserves a fair chance to succeed
Her fair skin burned easily in the sun
The child had fair hair and blue eyes
They traveled a fair distance to reach us
She has a fair amount of experience
The forecast promised fair weather for the weekend
After the storm came several fair days
The fair maiden captured the knight's heart
She was considered the fairest in the land

definitions: remaining loyal and steadfast; showing consistent support or allegiance
true to facts, standards, or original; accurate in representation
examples: She remained faithful to her husband throughout their marriage
The faithful dog waited by the door every evening
The movie was faithful to the original novel
He gave a faithful account of what happened

definitions: not loyal or reliable; breaking faith or being treacherous to trust placed
examples: Her faithless friend revealed all her secrets
The faithless ally abandoned them in battle

definitions: not genuine; made to appear like something else in order to deceive
examples: The painting turned out to be a fake masterpiece
She wore fake diamonds to the party

definitions: having dropped or come down from a higher position physically
having lost status, power, or moral standing; degraded or corrupted
killed in battle or military service, used especially as honorific
examples: The fallen leaves covered the forest path
A fallen tree blocked the road ahead
The fallen angel was cast out of heaven
She helped fallen women find new opportunities
They honored the fallen soldiers at the memorial
The fallen heroes were remembered with gratitude

definitions: moving downward under the force of gravity; descending
decreasing in number, amount, intensity, or value
examples: Falling rain soaked through their clothes
The falling snow created a winter wonderland
Falling prices attracted more buyers to the market
Her falling grades concerned her parents

definitions: of farmland plowed and left unseeded for a season or more to restore fertility
characterized by inactivity or lack of development; dormant or unused
examples: The farmer left the field fallow to restore nutrients
Fallow land stretched for miles around the village
After years of fallow creativity, she began painting again
The project remained fallow for lack of funding

definitions: not according with truth or fact; incorrect or wrong
made to imitate something else; not genuine or real
deliberately intended to deceive or mislead; treacherous
examples: The witness gave false information to police
His false assumption led to wrong conclusions
She wore false eyelashes to the party
The false ceiling hid the ventilation system
He presented a false identity to border guards
Her false friend spread rumors behind her back

definitions: of or using an artificially high voice, especially by male singers
examples: The singer's falsetto voice reached incredible high notes
He sang the chorus in a beautiful falsetto

definitions: losing strength or momentum; beginning to fail or give way
moving or speaking in a hesitant or unsteady way; wavering
examples: The faltering economy worried investors and workers alike
His faltering health required constant medical attention
She spoke in a faltering voice during the speech
He took faltering steps after the long illness

definitions: famous and widely known, especially for a particular quality or achievement
examples: The famed scientist won multiple Nobel prizes
They visited the famed cathedral in Paris

definitions: relating to or occurring in a family or its members; characteristic of family
examples: Strong familial bonds kept the siblings close
The disease has a familial pattern of inheritance

definitions: well known from long or close association; easily recognized
informal or friendly in manner; showing lack of proper respect
examples: The familiar landscape comforted her after traveling
His familiar voice calmed the frightened children
His familiar tone annoyed his formal supervisor
She was too familiar with the important guests

definitions: known about by many people; having celebrity or wide recognition
examples: The famous actor signed autographs for waiting fans
Paris is famous for its romantic atmosphere

definitions: filled with excessive and single-minded zeal, especially about religious or political beliefs
examples: The fanatic followers refused to question their leader
His fanatic devotion to fitness dominated his life

definitions: filled with or expressing excessive zeal or enthusiasm in an extreme way
examples: Her fanatical dedication to work worried her family
The team's fanatical supporters never missed a game

definitions: existing only in imagination or as an unfounded belief
expected to do well or win, especially in sports competitions
examples: Her fancied grievances had no basis in reality
The fancied danger turned out to be nothing
The heavily fancied team lost in the finals
He was the fancied candidate for the position

definitions: overimaginative and unrealistic; existing only in imagination rather than reality
examples: Her fanciful ideas rarely worked in practice
The child told fanciful stories about dragons

definitions: elaborate in structure or decoration; ornamental rather than plain
expensive, superior, or high quality; sophisticated or refined
examples: She wore a fancy dress to the wedding
The fancy decorations impressed all the guests
They dined at a fancy restaurant downtown
His fancy car attracted everyone's attention

definitions: spread out in the shape of a fan or semicircle
examples: The peacock's fanned tail displayed brilliant colors
Cards were fanned across the table
